description: From Ancient Greek αὐξησις (auxēsis, “growth”), from αὐξάνειν (auxánein, “to grow”).

definitionGroups.group: (rhetoric) A rhetorical device whereby the subject matter is made greater, particularly

examples: Avxesis, when we vse a greater word for a lesse, or thus, when the word is greater then the thing is in deede.

entries.meaning: (rhetoric, obsolete) Arrangement of a series in ascending order.
(biology) Biological growth, (now usually restricted to) expansion or growth of an organism apart from that due to cellular division.
examples: Botanists do still distinguish between auxesis or growth by expansion, and merisis or growth by cell-multiplication.
